column1: # This table is based on a homonym table provided by the Holos source code:
# The original table and associated comments are commented in the following lines

column2: Solid storage - with or without litter (12)

column1: # "Data on manure composition were organized from multiple publications based on Canadian studies (extension documents
column3: journal publications). Where data from Canada were not available
column4: data were sourced from outside Canada – any non-Canadian data used is indicated in the relevant notes below."

column2: C and P content for beef cattle manure deposited on pasture were derived from unpublished data (provided by X. Hao
column3: AAFC). For all other animals on pasture (dairy cattle
column6: N and P content values for beef cattle were used where needed
column7: due to a lack of available data for these groups."

column1: # "2 Default values for moisture content and N
column2: C and P content for deep bedding manure for beef cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1994); Hao et al. (2001
column5: 2014); Whalen et al. (2002); Miller et al. (2003
column7: 2009); Helgason et al. (2005); Larney and Olson (2006); Larney et al. (2006); Zvomuya et al. (2006); Stefankiw (2012). These values were also used for deep bedding for dairy cattle."

column1: # "3 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for solid storage (stockpiled) manure for beef cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1993); Olson and Papworth (2002); Sommer et al. (2004); Loro (2005); Pattey et al. (2005); Larney et al. (2006); The Prairie Provinces’ Committee on Livestock Development and Manure Management (2006a
column3: b); Government of Manitoba (2009); Brown (2013). For sheep and other livestock manure in solid storage
column4: the Ccontent for beef cattle manure for solid storage (stockpiled) was used."

column1: # "4 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for composted passive manure for beef cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1989
column4: 1994); Pattey et al. (2005); Larney and Olson (2006); Larney et al. (2006)."

column1: # "5 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for composted intensive manure for beef cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Miller et al. (2004
column4: 2014); Helgason et al. (2005); Larney and Olson (2006); Zvomuya et al. (2006); Larney et al. (2008

column1: # "6 The Ncontent of excreted dairy manure (urine + feces) deposited on pasture is from Nennich et al. (2005) as follows: lactating cow: 0.653%; dry cow: 0.591%; heifer: 0.478%; calf: 0.508% (these values were calculated using data in Table 4 in Nennich et al) - as the Ncontent varies so too does the C:N ratio
column2: depending on the animal group; the Pcontent of excreted dairy manure was calculated using data for dairy cows from Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006)."

column1: # "7 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for solid storage (stockpiled) manure for dairy cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Pattey et al. (2005); Government of Manitoba (2009); Brown (2013); Manitoba Agriculture
column3: Food and Rural Development (2015); Fillingham et al. (2017); Ackerman et al. (2018)."

column1: # "8 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for composted manure (incl. composted separated solids) for dairy cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1989
column3: 1993); Pattey et al. (2005); Cambareri et al. (2017); Fillingham et al. (2017). The same values are applied to composted passive and composted intensive dairy manure."

column1: # "9 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for composted manure for swine (liquid manure mixed with straw composted in-vessel) were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Thompson et al. (2004); Park et al. (2014)."

column1: # "10 Values for moisture content of sheep manure (as excreted) from Bell (1983); Ncontent was calculated using data from ECCC (2021) and Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006); Pcontent was calculated from Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006)."
# "11 Default values for moisture content and N and P content for solid sheep manure were averages calculated from data derived from Brown (2013)."
# "12 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for solid poultry manure were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1989); Government of Manitoba (2009); Brown (2013); Manitoba Agriculture
column3: Food and Rural Development (2015); Sukler et al. (2015); Government of Alberta (2021)."

column1: # "13 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for sheep manure deposited on pasture were applied to llama and alpaca manure deposited on pasture; the moisture content for sheep manure deposited on pasture was applied to goat manure deposited on pasture."

column1: # "14 The Ncontent of goat manure deposited on pasture was calculated using data from ECCC (2021) and Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006); Pcontent was calculated from Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006)."
# "15 Default values for moisture content for horse manure deposited on pasture were derived from Bell (1983)
column2: for Ncontent from Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006) and ECCC (2021)
column3: and for Pcontent from Hofmann and Beaulieu (2006)."

column2: Ncontent and Pcontent values for horses on pasture used for mules on pasture."

column3: Ccontent and Pcontent values for beef cattle on pasture used for bison on pasture."

column2: Ncontent and Pcontent values for sheep manure in solid storage are used for llama and alpaca manure in solid storage (drylot)."
Ncontent and Pcontent values for deer/elk manure in solid storage (drylot) were derived from Government of Alberta (2013
Ncontent and Pcontent values for manure in solid storage (drylot) for goats derived from Brown (2013); Government of Alberta (2013)."
Ncontent and Pcontent for horse manure in solid storage (drylot) were derived from: Brown (2013); Government of Alberta (2013
Ncotent and Pcontent values for horse manure in solid storage are used for mule manure in solid storage (drylot)."
Ncontent and Pcontent for bison manure in solid storage (drylot) were derived from: Government of Alberta (2013

column1: # "24 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for liquid/slurry manure for dairy cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1989
column3: 1993); Pattey et al. (2005); The Prairie Provinces’ Committee on Livestock Development and Manure Management (2006a); Government of Manitoba (2009); VanderZaag et al. (2009
column6: Food and Rural Development (2015); LeRiche et al. (2016); Ngwabie et al. (2016); Fillingham et al. (2017); Ackerman et al. (2018); Balde et al. (2018); Johannesson et al. (2018); Kariyapperuma et al. (2018a
column7: b); Maldaner et al. (2018). These default values are used for all dairy liquid/slurry manure types: ""Daily spread""
column10: ""Liquid with solid cover"" and ""Deep pit under barn"" (pit storage below animal confinement)."

column1: # "25 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P fractions for anaerobic digestate for dairy cattle were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Balde et al. (2018); Evans et al. (2018); Maldaner et al (2018)."

column1: # "26 Default values for moisture content and C
column2: N and P content for liquid/slurry for swine were averages calculated from data derived from the following sources: Paul and Beauchamp (1989); Fitzgerald and Racz (2001); Olson and Papworth (2002); Dick (2003); Thompson et al. (2004); The Prairie Provinces’ Committee on Livestock Development and Manure Management (2006a
column3: b); Government of Manitoba (2009); Coppi (2012); Brown (2013); Tenuta et al. (2013); Park et al. (2014); Manitoba Agriculture
column4: Food and Rural Development (2015). These default values are used for all swine liquid/slurry manure types: ""Liquid with natural crust""
column6: ""Liquid with solid cover"" And ""Deep pit under barn"" (pit storage below animal confinement)."

column1: # "27 Default values for volatile solids (VS) content (% wet weight) were derived from the following sources: Beef cattle (deep bedding) - Wedwitschka et al. (2021); Beef cattle (solid storage
column2: compost - passive windrow and compost - active windrow) - values used are for dairy cattle solid storage and composted manure; Dairy cattle (deep bedding) - value used is for beef cattle deep bedding; Dairy cattle (solid storage) - Ackerman et al. (2018)
column3: Fillingham et al. (2017); Dairy cattle (compost - passive windrow and compost - active windrow) - Fillingham et al. (2017); Swine (composted in-vessel) - value used is for dairy cattle composted manure; Sheep (solid storage) - value used is for dairy cattle solid storage manure; Poultry (solid storage - with or without litter) - Farrow (2016)
column5: liquid/slurry with and without natural crust) - Dalby et al. (2021); Dairy cattle (liquid/slurry with solid cover and deep pit under barn) - Dalby et al. (2021)
column6: Johanesson et al. (2015); Swine (liquid/slurry with and without natural crust) - Dalby et al. (2021)
column7: VanderZaag et al. (2021); Swine (liquid/slurry with solid cover and deep pit under barn) - Dalby et al. (2021)
